Currently in Virginia, law enforcement can seize your money or property if it believes it may have been used in the commission of a crime, even without a conviction. This needs to change.
  

Support HB 900 and SB 341!

Take action now to end policing for profit!

Dear ##first_name[Supporter]##,

There's a dirty little secret that law enforcement agencies in Virginia are padding their budgets by taking what isn't theirs.

It's called civil asset forfeiture, also known as policing for profit.

Tell your delegate and senator you support requiring a conviction before law enforcement can seize and keep anyone's money or property.

Under Virginia law, police can pull you over, and if they have probable cause, they can take your money or property and make you prove it didn't come from a criminal enterprise. They don't even need to charge you with a crime. It's unbelievable – and so out of control that Virginia police and prosecutors collected $5.4 million from state forfeitures in 2017 and another $8 million plus from federal forfeitures.

Civil asset forfeiture is a by-product of the failed War on Drugs. It gives police and prosecutors a cash incentive to stop and search Virginians. If an agency is able to show they had "probable cause" for a search, they can "seize" cash and property they say are probably related to a drug offense. Then, in a trial, it is up to the owner of the property to appear and prove that the property shouldn't be subject to forfeiture. If the owner cannot provide adequate proof, the law enforcement agency may keep up to 90 percent of the assets forfeited.

The deck is so stacked in their favor that the Virginia State Police and local agencies are budgeting in advance based on what revenues they expect to get in the future from seized assets. Policing should be based on public safety, not revenue expectations built into a department's budget.

Let your state delegate and senator know that the time to end the immoral practice of policing for profit is now!

Sincerely,


Claire G. Gastanaga
Executive Director
ACLU of Virginia
